narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Much of this same material was covered in Landscape Ecology.

Q4 - the workload was very high compared to F&ES standards (which are generally low, in my opinion). It is refreshing to find a course that demands highly of the students, however, the deadlines for some assessments were not well planned and we ended up having to deliver 2 papers with 3 day difference, which made that week a very tough one.Q9- the syllabus mentioned 3 labs that ended up just being discussions instead of hands-on activities. If they are not real labs they should not be advertised as such.

Questions 2, 6&8: This course was taught with a strong ecological and evolutionary Biology bias which i thought was great for me. The course was however brief on the social front of conservation i.e. the people-environment interface such as in collaborative decision making; community participation in conservation planning and implementation. The course was good in the area of how to communicate to a decision maker such as a Politician. Generally, the Professor thoroughly pursued "evidence-based" i.e., conservation with sound scientific basis throughout the course.

This class was somewhat mixed--some sections were well taught and very interesting while others seemed a little scattered. Overall it tried to cover too much ground and so didn't get too in depth on any subject. Best parts focused on ecology and science, was a little weaker in the policy or economic sections. Dr. Schmitz can be somewhat intimidating in class and seems a little annoyed with us, but is obviously passionate about the material.
I like the broad range of concepts covered in class.
The concept assessments required critical thinking and there were no rote tests.
The depth of the course. This is a very good concentration course.
- liking science and policy (or at least attempting to)- very applied assignments- no stressful exams
The lectures were really interesting

1. The subject matter - this is the only course of its kind at FES.2. The assignments really pushed the student to delve into the sci. literature to learn about and grasp the material3. The final concept assessment was one of the best assignments a teacher has ever offered4. I appreciated the complementarity of the mid-term (sci-based review) and the final project (policy oriented deliverable)5. Schmitz brought in practitioners to discuss class topics and to meet with students. Really great/valuable experience.6. The course pushed students to think about their role as sci/policy makers, gave them increased familiarity with the sci literature/research, the freedom and flexibility to craft their own projects, and great lessons to challenge them to think critically about conventional conservation practices - outstanding.

The intensive literature review for concpet assessments were a major hightlight of the course, i think this is what i learned most in class. the best thing about this course is the up to date readings we have, and the latest ressearch in the realm of ecology and policy.
The insistence on "evidence-based-conservation".
The broad topics covered.
Os is an excellent lecturer and he covers a very broad range of topics. Some students wanted more specificity on a smaller range, but this was good for me.
Assignments provided the opportunity to pursue research on specific topics of interest. Professor Schmitz set an ambitious agenda and covered most of what he set out to cover.

It kept abreast with the current knowledge of the subject. The instructor tried to disapprove the conventional approaches to conservation and presented the new idea/thinking on different facets of biodiversity conservation. He insisted on evidence-based conservation to minimize the costs of committing type II error. It is one of the very useful class I have taken at F&ES.
The organization and broad topic coverage

Really liked the final assignment. Taking a challenging conservation issue, researching and presenting all the scientific evidence, and then using that piece to draw a policy memo with action steps for decision makers, was a real worthwhile assignment.

Learning practical tools and skills for biodiversity conservation, and getting to hear from practicioners in the field, and see how the policy and science interact.Also, the final paper/project was a very interesting assignment that I got a lot out of.

The big term assignment was a good project and most people learned a lot--it was well structured into the two sections and was great to get much of it done early in the semester. I liked the mix of freedom to chose a topic that was relevant to your own interests, but also some structure about possible questions to look at.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: We shouldn't get the "I'm really disappointed in you" lecture when the instructor gives very broad and general instructions for assignments. I felt like is was not very effective teaching.

The expectations for the first concept assessment was very unclear. We were presented with what amounted to a trick question, and were berated by the professor when most of us did not realize it was a trick question.
Smoothen the workload throughout the semester (perhaps less discussion sessions, plan deadlines better...)
- a way to force us to remember the information we're taught since there are no exams- more instructions in the beginning on what the professor is looking for in assignments
The assignments and clarity of the assignments. There was really no need for the amount of research that was assigned. I believe it was actually detrimental to learning the course content.

Material is covered too quickly (on the per class-session and semester scale).Lessons should be tied together more explicitly.Prerequisite or recommendation for Excel-based experience should be noted in course descriptionConsider inviting an economist to introduce ecosystem services and then discuss with Os how this can/does align/deviate from other ecological perspectivesThe theme of stewardship should be integrated into the semester - a key point but seemed rather abrupt in its introduction at the end of the semester

i was confused of the perspectives in which we were taught- i am not sure if it was mainly prof's personal opinion or the general public's viewpoint. i would like to know the more objective scientific knowledge. concpet assessments were a bit unclear in terms of their wording, i was unsure to which direction to work on. but this had improved towards the last few CA.

1. Some context on conflict resolution and conservation issues. An example of the latter could be human-animal conflict. It could also be animal-human conflict.2. Some lectures and discussions on conservation and sustainable development.

Clarification of expectation. More important than the material covered or teaching quality, expectations of the students and of what the class would cover were not aligned with what ended up being covered or done in the course.
Really we need a broad intro course like this and them more specific courses fleshing out some of the concepts.
The class might be split into two iterations, one geared toward MEM students and one for MESc students.

I know Professor Schmitz is trying to meet the needs of multiple students by making the class accessible to those with less of a conservation background and by covering multiple topics. I still think the course would be better if he focused in more detail on fewer topics.At time there was some miscommunication between the professor and students as to the expectations for assignments. I think we may have done better more quickly had the professor been more explicit about his expectations.

The instructor needs to be a little friendly from the start. Initially, he was so intimidating. But as course progressed, he became friendlier. I understand that he was trying to be polemic to provoke students to think and fix ideas.
Lighten the work load a little. More time on ecosystem services.

Expectations should be laid about from the beginning as to precisely what the instructor wants for a "quality" assignment. I believe the first assignment, the buffalo population problem, was a bit confusing as to what was expected. Also, perhaps a little less breadth of issues for biodiversity conservation in order to delve more deeply into a few "key" concerns for the discipline area. I felt that towards the end of the course, concepts became very broad and generalized, leaving few concrete ideas for ways forward.

At the beginning of the semester, I was unclear on the expectations for some of the assignments - this improved later on. Also I would have liked to expand on some of the topics of the first several weeks of the semester.

Expectations for grading were not always clear. There was no syllabus in terms of overall number of assignments, when they would be do, etc., which was a little confusing. We never really got into any of the topics in depth. Sometimes Os gets a little out of his element. Also, the discussion section was not very useful and took up a lot of time. Much of the material was almost lifted directly from previous classes (including slides).

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: The TA, Holly, was very approachable and helpful. I never sought help from the Instructor.
I contacted the TA on several occasions and she was very responsive all the time.
I did not contact the professor for help but the TA was available the one time I did contact her. Quality of help was okay.
I contacted the TA for help and she was usually willing to help me.
Both were very considerate, provided timely responses, and were helpful.I do not recall if/when Os had office hours (i.e. not noted in syllabus, do not recall being discussed in class).
Intructor: the instructor was willing to help me in questions I had.TA: she was helpful with course material as well.

The Professor of this course offered valuable advice to me whenever i contacted him. He was very constructive in his approach.The TA too was helpful in advising us about the course and how to approach the varied problem sets
I contacted both TA and Professor for help and for outside advice regarding internships and found both really helpful.
I did not seek help with coursework.

Holly Jones openly complained about the amount of work she had to do and claimed she was not payed enough for the work done. I think this is an inappropriate discussion to have with her students, especially during sections she was leading. She made it obvious that she was not happy about having to grade our final projects, which makes it difficult to want to work on the final projects. As compared to other TAs I have had at F&ES, I was very disappointed with Holly.
Excellent. They both were very helpful.
I found the discussion sections with the TA very helpful at clearing up any confusion from the class lectures and continuing the discussion of interesting topics.
Seemed open to give help, I never asked.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: The class is directly applicable to land conservation and management.

I think this course definitely helps with my career objective as i wish to pursue in wildlife conservation. However, taking the course in the first semester was quite heavy for me in addition to my three other heavy writing course work. that said, i still think this course had changed my rooted concepts in many ways. this serves as a fundamental understadning for me in ecology and biodiversity.

In general, the course opened my horizon much more, compared to my previous training in conservation biology. This is especially true for population viability analysis in conservation science and practice. The latter is crucial to sound decision making in conservation science and practice. In that connection, this course fits into my future work with endangered species.

This course fits in well with my program as a Master of Forestry candidate. I wish there was a similar course focusing on forest conservation more specifically, but in the absence of that, this is a great substitute.
I am a wildlife manager. So, this course fits perfectly to my overall program.
I considered this course essential to my overall program, since I focus on conservation of biodiersity.
Seemed like it would be a cornerstone class for someone interested in wildlife conservation--topics were interesting but mostly review from other classes.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: It fit well in my study of land management and conservation.
I needed a concentration course and I had done nothing on ecology since my undergrad.
To gain a better understanding of wildlife sciences.
Personal and professional interest in biodiversity conservation
same reasons as mentioned above.

I wanted to question what i already knew before taking the course. And i think, the Professor did a good job at helping me re-think some paradigms i have known forever. An example is, the need to critically examine the source(s) of a data set available for decision making about an endangered species; how far did the data go...?
I took this course to provide structure to continued study of ecological theory and practice.

Because I wanted to learn new and sophisticated approaches to biodiversity conservation. I wanted to understand the threats to biodiversity and how best to tackle them. And what are the frontiers in biodiversity conservation/science.
I did not have much background in conservation or ecosystems.
Interested in biodiversity conservation, challenges and opportunities!
To learn more about biodiversity conservation.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: No. The requirements from students were sometimes unclear, and the caliper of work expected from the students was not complimented by high caliper teaching.
for the most part, although it's not a hard science course as Os made it out to be

Well I think the fact that this class is new and there were kinks to be worked out had much to do with this. The class wasn't what I expected but the professor addressed the issues at the end of the course and he discussed some of the changes he would make to the course in the future.
For the most part, yes - especially in challenging convention conservation practices
mostly.
Yes
I had anticipated this to be a more advanced science course. It seemed more geared toward management concerns.
Totally. Though I felt like time was not enough.
Yes. I think it could have benefited from some more basic information.

Yes and No. In some ways, I felt the assignments were worthwhile and demanding. However, forsome of the material presented, I would have preferred if we had gone into greater depth rather than a broad overview.
Yes, though I wish the course had been a little more advanced level as it was described initially.

Not entirely--it was not really an advanced course as it was advertised to be, and tried to be too many things to too many people. Would have been better to limit enrollment perhaps? A good intro to the topics for those new to them.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: I would have liked more practical knowledge with less general theory.
I actually got out more. I have learned many new interesting things tha have changed my way of perceiving ecosystems.
for the most part
Yes
For the most part, yes.
yes.

I did not get my usual expectation. I however think the course provided me with a more critical and analytical insight into conservation science and practice. Which i think is critical to my future work.
Yes
I didn't get from this course exactly what I had anticipated but benefited in ways I had not anticipated.

Yes. I learned a lot of new things. I walked out of this class a different person. From this class I learned that most of our conservation approaches back home (Africa) are against what is supposed to be done.

The experience researching different conservation questions was useful, as was the final project. Definitely got a good in depth knowledge of my topic. The speakers were not as helpful as I had hoped.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: This course is more aimed at policy than science!
Be prepared for a tremendous amount of work. Plan to take this class when your course-load is light because you will fall behind in your other courses.

Push the envelope on all assignments, even if it does not seem like the query warrants it. In doing so, use EVIDENCE-BASED arguments.Familiarize yourself with Excel - it's only applicable for the first few weeks but still will help a great deal.Enjoy - you'll learn a lot.
1. have backgrounds in ecology and evolutionary biology2. should limit other three courses to less demanding, as this is a highly demanding course
Go for it! Go prepared to think "outside-the-box"
Talk to previous students about the course before you make a decision. The topic appeals to a wide variety of students, but the level of information won't be appealing to everyone.
Talk with Professor Schmitz about this course before taking it. Know the planned approach, beyond what is contained in a syllabus or reading list.
For the new generation of conservationists, this course is a must.
Just like any other course, the more reading and work you put into it the more you'll get out of it. Also, be prepared to participate in lecture.
Budget plenty of time to work on the concept assessments, and be aware that this is a science AND policy course going into it.

If you have a lot of experience in the topic or have taken other ecology classes here, there is a lot of repetition. The work is pretty heavy (though not difficult), there are a lot of assignments and grading can be tough. But the reading is pretty good and most of the assignments were interesting and useful.
